title: Secrets of the X chromosome - Robin Ball

multiple-choice.question: What determines the physical traits of humans?

options.label: B
options.text: Long, coiled strands of DNA in the nucleus

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the Y chromosome?

options.label: B
options.text: To determine biological sex and fertility in males

options.label: C
options.text: To control the development of the nervous system

multiple-choice.question: What is X inactivation, and why is it necessary?

options.label: A
options.text: X inactivation is the process by which the X chromosome is duplicated, and it is necessary for male development.

options.label: B
options.text: X inactivation is the process by which one X chromosome is inactivated, and it is necessary to prevent impaired development in individuals with two X chromosomes.

options.label: C
options.text: X inactivation is the process by which the Y chromosome is inactivated, and it is necessary for female development.

options.label: D
options.text: X inactivation is the process by which both X chromosomes are inactivated, and it is necessary for embryonic development.

multiple-choice.question: Why do calico cats have patches of different colors?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have different genes for each color

options.label: B
options.text: Because of X inactivation, which causes different cells to express different X chromosomes

options.label: C
options.text: Because of mutations in the genes that control coat color

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the interaction between the X and Y chromosomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the difference in color vision between the identical twins?

options.label: A
options.text: One twin has a mutation in the gene that controls color vision

options.label: B
options.text: The twins have different X inactivation patterns, resulting in one twin having a mutant copy of the green receptor gene in the cells that became eyes

options.label: C
options.text: The twins have different versions of the gene that controls color vision

options.label: D
options.text: The twins have different numbers of X chromosomes

multiple-choice.question: Why are disorders associated with X chromosome mutations often less severe in individuals with two X chromosomes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mutant gene is always inactivated

options.label: B
options.text: Because only some cells are affected by the mutation due to X inactivation

options.label: C
options.text: Because the normal gene is always dominant

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mutant gene is always expressed

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if an individual with only one X chromosome inherited a mutant copy of a gene?

options.label: A
options.text: The individual would not be affected by the mutation

options.label: B
options.text: The individual would be less severely affected by the mutation

options.label: C
options.text: The individual would be more severely affected by the mutation

options.label: D
options.text: The individual would not express the mutant gene

multiple-choice.question: What is a Barr body, and what is its significance in X inactivation?

options.label: A
options.text: A Barr body is an active X chromosome, and it is significant because it determines the sex of the individual.

options.label: B
options.text: A Barr body is an inactive X chromosome, and it is significant because it shows that X inactivation has occurred.

options.label: C
options.text: A Barr body is a mutant gene, and it is significant because it causes disorders.

options.label: D
options.text: A Barr body is a protein, and it is significant because it regulates gene expression.

multiple-choice.question: How does X inactivation affect the expression of genes on the X chromosome?

options.label: A
options.text: X inactivation causes all genes on the X chromosome to be expressed

options.label: B
options.text: X inactivation causes some genes on the X chromosome to be expressed, while others are inactivated

options.label: C
options.text: X inactivation causes all genes on the X chromosome to be inactivated

options.label: D
options.text: X inactivation has no effect on gene expression

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the unresolved questions about X inactivation?

options.label: A
options.text: How X inactivation determines the sex of the individual

options.label: B
options.text: Why X inactivation is necessary for development

options.label: C
options.text: How some genes on the X chromosome escape inactivation

options.label: D
options.text: Why X inactivation is always random

title: Why do we itch? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of histamine in the body's response to a mosquito bite?

options.label: B
options.text: To trigger the release of anticoagulants

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of natriuretic polypetide B in the sensation of itching?

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the sensation of itching by releasing histamine

options.label: C
options.text: It causes a low-level pain signal that overrides the itching sensation

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in the sensation of itching

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A skin condition where people experience redness and swelling

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the sensation of itching
